sen.j: 和楽器（わがっき）とは、日本で、古来から使われてきた伝統的な楽器のことである。
sen.e: A Wagakki (traditional Japanese musical instrument) refers to a traditional musical instrument which has been used in Japan from ancient times.
Wagakki is a term used to refer to traditional musical instruments that have been used in Japan from ancient times.
sen.cmt: Providing a short explanation in parentheses in the title is helpful to the reader but as this sentence already explains what Wagakki means, there is no need to repeat the explanation in parentheses here.
sen.e: Wagakki is a term used to refer to traditional musical instruments that have been used in Japan from ancient times.

sen.j: 邦楽器とも呼ぶ。
sen.e: It is also referred to as a Hogakki (Japanese musical instrument).
Such instruments are also referred to as Hogakki.
Such instruments are also referred to as Hogakki.

sen.j: 弥生時代から続く和琴 (わごん) や起源不明の胡弓など一部を除き、大陸に由来するものがほとんどである。
sen.e: Most of Wagakkis are originated from the Asian continent except those, such as Wagons (transverse harps with a wooden body and silk strings) which have been present since the Yayoi period and Kokyus (oriental stringed musical instruments played with a bow) the origin of which is unknown.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: With the exception of instruments such as the Wagon (a six-stringed flat zither that was invented in the Yayoi period) and the Kokyu (a three- or four-stringed bowed instrument whose origins are unknown), most Wagakki are originally from the Asian continent.
sen.cmt: We usually use the singular with the definite article when talking about a type of musical instruments (and foreign words that don't have singular/plural forms in the original language are often left unchanged when used as a plural in English, anyway), so I don't think an "s" should be used here to make the names of these instruments plural. The edited version of this sentence differs from the Japanese a little in terms of structure (i.e. I have shifted some of the information into the parentheses) but it reads more naturally this way, I think.
sen.e: With the exception of instruments such as the Wagon (a six-stringed flat zither that was invented in the Yayoi period) and the Kokyu (a three- or four-stringed bowed instrument whose origins are unknown), most Wagakki are originally from the Asian continent.

sen.j: 「雅楽の琵琶」 (楽琵琶) のように、大陸では失われてしまった古い姿を残している楽器も多いが、「三味線」「尺八」「能囃子」「能囃子・能囃子」のように独特な進化を遂げたものもある。
sen.e: While many of Wagakkis, such as "Biwas for Gagaku" (Gaku-biwas) (Japanese traditional lutes for Japanese traditional music and dance), still keep their original old forms which have already disappeared in the Asian continent, the others, such as Shamisens (three stringed musical instruments), Shakuhachis (Japanese end-blown flutes), Nohkans (air reed musical instruments for Noh), and Ko-tsuzumi and O-tsuzumi (small and large percussion musical instruments for Noh), have developed in a unique fashion in Japan.
sen.cmt: (1) 一原文一訳文の例外対処、 (2) 原文の”「能囃子」「能囃子・能囃子」”の部分は、内容が重複しており、なんらかの誤りではないかと推察致します。インターネット上のWikipediaの該当部分をチェックしたところ、この部分は、”「能管」「小鼓・大鼓」”となっておりました。従って、訳文も、これが「能管」「小鼓・大鼓」であるものとして訳出致しました。
sen.e: While many Wagakki, such as the "Gagaku Biwa" (a Japanese lute traditionally used for ceremonial court music), have retained their original forms (and these forms can no longer be found in mainland Asian), other instruments, such as the Shamisen (a three-stringed musical instrument), the Shakuhachi (a five-holed traverse bamboo flute), the Nohkan (a traverse flute used in Noh), and the Ko-tsuzumi and O-tsuzumi (small and large drums, respectively, that are used in Noh), have developed in a unique fashion in Japan.
sen.cmt: The correct reading for "雅楽" is "gagaku", I think.
sen.e: While many Wagakki, such as the "Gagaku Biwa" (a Japanese lute traditionally used for ceremonial court music), have retained their original forms (and these forms can no longer be found in mainland Asian), other instruments, such as the Shamisen (a three-stringed musical instrument), the Shakuhachi (a five-holed traverse bamboo flute), the Nohkan (a traverse flute used in Noh), and the Ko-tsuzumi and O-tsuzumi (small and large drums, respectively, that are used in Noh), have developed in a unique fashion in Japan.

sen.j: アイヌ音楽の楽器であるムックリやトンコリ、沖縄音楽の楽器三線もこの項の解説に含む。
sen.e: Musical instruments for Ainu music, such as Mukkuris and Tonkoris, and musical instruments for Okinawa music, such as Sanshins, are also described in this section.
Musical instruments for Ainu music, such as the Mukkuri and Tonkori, and musical instruments for Okinawan music, such as the Sanshin, are also described in this section.
Musical instruments for Ainu music, such as the Mukkuri and Tonkori, and musical instruments for Okinawan music, such as the Sanshin, are also described in this section.

sen.j: 和楽器はきわめてデリケートな音色の変化を尊重、追求する。
sen.e: In Wagakkis, delicate changes in tones are highly appreciated and chased.
In Wagakki, delicate changes in tones are sought after and highly appreciated.
In Wagakki, delicate changes in tones are sought after and highly appreciated.

sen.j: そのため、特に室内系和楽器の音色の洗練度は非常に高い。
sen.e: For this reason, tones of Wagakkis for chamber music are, in particular, highly sophisticated.
For this reason, the tones of Wagakki for chamber music are, in particular, very sophisticated.
For this reason, the tones of Wagakki for chamber music are, in particular, very sophisticated.

sen.j: 例えば三味線は駒 (弦楽器)ひとつで大きく音色が変化する。
sen.e: For example, tones of Shamisens may change greatly even when only their bridges (stringed musical instrument) are replaced.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For example, the tones of the Shamisen may change greatly even when only its bridge (a component of a stringed musical instrument) is replaced.
For example, the tones of the Shamisen may change greatly even when only its bridge (a component of a stringed musical instrument) is replaced.

sen.j: 中でも地歌三味線では、一人の奏者が何個もの駒を持ち、その日の天候、楽器のコンディション、曲の雰囲気などに合わせて使い分ける。
sen.e: In particular, for Jiuta-shamisens, one player carries several bridges and selects the most appropriate one depending on the weather, the condition of the instrument, nature of the music to be played, etc.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Particularly, for the Jiuta-shamisens one player carries several bridges and selects the most appropriate one depending on the weather, the condition of the instrument, the nature of the music to be played, etc.

Particularly, for the Jiuta-shamisens one player carries several bridges and selects the most appropriate one depending on the weather, the condition of the instrument, the nature of the music to be played, etc.

sen.j: 駒そのものも重さなど実にデリケートな差異による追求がなされている。
sen.e: There are a wide variety of bridges available in terms of weight, etc., which enable players to provide the audience with delicate differences.
Bridges are available in wide varieties with regard to weight, etc., so that the player can offer the audience subtle differences in sound.
Bridges are available in wide varieties with regard to weight, etc., so that the player can offer the audience subtle differences in sound.

sen.j: また洋楽器が操作機能や音域拡大、分担化の追求により分化、発展したのに比べ、和楽器は音色の追求により分化、発展したといえる。
sen.e: Furthermore, it can also be said that while Western musical instruments have developed and diversified by chasing better manipulation features, larger tessitura, and higher level of specialization, Wagakkis have developed and diversified by chasing more beautiful tones.

Furthermore, it can also be said that while Western musical instruments have developed and diversified through the pursuit of better manipulation features, larger tessitura and higher levels of specialization, Wagakki have developed and diversified through the pursuit of more beautiful tones.

Furthermore, it can also be said that while Western musical instruments have developed and diversified through the pursuit of better manipulation features, larger tessitura and higher levels of specialization, Wagakki have developed and diversified through the pursuit of more beautiful tones.

sen.j: 三味線音楽の種目ごとに楽器各部や撥、駒 (弦楽器)、弦 (楽器) (糸) に微妙な違いがあるのがその好例である。
sen.e: As a typical example, in the case of Shamisens, slightly different instrument bodies, plectrums, bridges (stringed musical instrument), and strings (musical instrument) (strings) are provided for each category of Shamisen music.

As a typical example, in the case of the Shamisen, slightly different instrument bodies, plectrums, bridges (components of stringed musical instruments) and strings (for musical instruments) are provided for each category of Shamisen music.

As a typical example, in the case of the Shamisen, slightly different instrument bodies, plectrums, bridges (components of stringed musical instruments) and strings (for musical instruments) are provided for each category of Shamisen music.

sen.j: 胡弓の弓 (楽器)も、ヴァイオリンの弓が機能的に改良されたのとは違って、音色の追求により改良され現在の形になった。
sen.e: Bows for Kokyus (musical instrument) have also been improved by chasing more beautiful tones while bows for violins have been improved in terms of their functions.
The bow for the Kokyu (musical instrument) has also been improved by chasing more beautiful tones, while bows for violins have been improved in terms of functionality.
The bow for the Kokyu (musical instrument) has also been improved by chasing more beautiful tones, while bows for violins have been improved in terms of functionality.

sen.j: 弦楽器は現在でも絹糸の弦にこだわるが（箏は経済的な事情でポリエステルが多くなった）、これも絹糸でしか出せない音色を尊重するからである。
sen.e: Silk strings are still used in most of stringed Wagakkis (although for Sos, polyester strings are starting to be commoly used due to economical reasons), and this is because beautiful tones, which can be generated only by silk strings, are highly appreciated.

Silk strings are still used in most stringed Wagakki (although, for the So, polyester strings are becoming common for economic reasons), and this is because beautiful tones, which can be generated only by silk strings, are highly appreciated.

Silk strings are still used in most stringed Wagakki (although, for the So, polyester strings are becoming common for economic reasons), and this is because beautiful tones, which can be generated only by silk strings, are highly appreciated.

sen.j: また、多くの楽器で音色技法が発達していおり、特に西洋音楽では現代になってやっと雑音的 (噪音) 要素を取り入れるようになったのに比べ、和楽器では早くから雑音の美が認められ、雑音的な要素までもが様々に取り入れられていることは大きな特徴である。
sen.e: In addition, techniques for generating various tones have advanced a lot in most of Wagakkis, and in particular, while Western music has stated to introduce noise elements recently, Wagakkis are characterized in that beauty of noises has been recognized from ancient times, and noise elements have been introduced in various manners.
sen.cmt: この原文の冒頭には、なにかが欠落しております。インターネット上のWikipediaの該当部分をチェックしたところ、「また、多くの楽器で音色技法が発達している。特に西洋音楽では現代になってやっと雑音的 (噪音」という文言が欠落していることが判明致しました。ついては、訳文も、これが原文の冒頭部分に存在するものとして訳出致しました。
sen.e: Additionally, the techniques for generating various tones have advanced a great deal in most Wagakki, and in particular, while Western music has recently started to introduce noise elements, Wagakki are characterized in that the beauty of noises has been recognized since ancient times, and noise elements have been introduced in various ways.

Additionally, the techniques for generating various tones have advanced a great deal in most Wagakki, and in particular, while Western music has recently started to introduce noise elements, Wagakki are characterized in that the beauty of noises has been recognized since ancient times, and noise elements have been introduced in various ways.

sen.j: 西洋音楽の楽器（洋楽器）では、和声音楽に用いる音から倍音以外を排除しようという方向性を持っていた。
sen.e: Musical instruments for Western music (Western musical instrument) had a tendency to eliminate sounds other than harmonic tones from sounds used for harmonic music.
Musical instruments for Western music (Western musical instruments) had a tendency to eliminate sounds other than harmonic tones from the sounds used for harmonic music.
Musical instruments for Western music (Western musical instruments) had a tendency to eliminate sounds other than harmonic tones from the sounds used for harmonic music.

sen.j: この違いは顕著で、また近隣の中国や朝鮮の音楽と比べても、和楽器には噪音（倍音以外の音）を多く含む音を出す楽器の比率が高い。
sen.e: This difference is conspicuous, and in the case of Wagakkis, the percentage of instruments that generate sounds including a large number of noises (or sounds other than harmonic tones) is high, even when compared with music of neighboring countries such as China and Korea.

This difference is conspicuous, and in the case of Wagakki the percentage of instruments that generate sounds, including a large number of noises (or sounds other than harmonic tones), is high, even by comparison to the music of neighboring countries such as China and Korea.

This difference is conspicuous, and in the case of Wagakki the percentage of instruments that generate sounds, including a large number of noises (or sounds other than harmonic tones), is high, even by comparison to the music of neighboring countries such as China and Korea.

sen.j: 三味線や楽琵琶を除く各種琵琶の雑音付加機構「さわり」はその代表例である。
sen.e: A Sawari mechanism, or a mechanism for adding noises, for Shamisens and various Biwas (except Gaku-biwas) is a typical example.
A Sawari mechanism, or a mechanism for adding noises, for the Shamisen and various Biwas (except the Gaku-biwa) is a typical example.
A Sawari mechanism, or a mechanism for adding noises, for the Shamisen and various Biwas (except the Gaku-biwa) is a typical example.

sen.j: また通常は噪音を出さない楽器でもわざわざ噪音を出す奏法がある。
sen.e: Furthermore, even in the case of instruments that normally do no generate noises, there exist special playing techniques to generate noises intentionally.
Furthermore, even in the case of instruments that normally don't generate noises there exist special playing techniques with which to generate noises intentionally.
Furthermore, even in the case of instruments that normally don't generate noises there exist special playing techniques with which to generate noises intentionally.

sen.j: これは、民族がそのような音を望んだからとしか説明のしようがない。
sen.e: This is because Japanese people preferred such sounds.
This is because Japanese people preferred such sounds.
This is because Japanese people preferred such sounds.

sen.j: 大陸から日本に伝来し、日本に定着する過程で、そのような変化、工夫が加わっていったものである。
sen.e: Such changes and innovations occurred in the process of adaptation in Japan after the introduction from the Asian continent.
Such changes and innovations occurred in the process of adaptation in Japan after their introduction from the Asian continent.
Such changes and innovations occurred in the process of adaptation in Japan after their introduction from the Asian continent.

sen.j: 西洋音楽の「モダン」な同属楽器と比較すると、音が小さいものが多い。
sen.e: Many of Wagakkis provide relatively lower sound volume levels than those of similar Western "modern" musical instruments.
Many Wagakki provide relatively lower sound volume levels than those of similar, "modern" Western instruments.
Many Wagakki provide relatively lower sound volume levels than those of similar, 'modern' Western instruments.

sen.j: 古典派音楽以降の西洋音楽ではコンサートホールのような広い空間で演奏するために大音量を要求された。
sen.e: Because Western music after the classical music has been played in a large space such as a concert hall, the musical instruments were required to provide higher sound volume levels.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because Western music, particularly since the emergence of orchestral music, has been played in large spaces such as concert halls, the musical instruments were required to provide higher sound levels.

Because Western music, particularly since the emergence of orchestral music, has been played in large spaces such as concert halls, the musical instruments were required to provide higher sound levels.

sen.j: そのために、音色の繊細さや演奏の容易さ、楽器自体の手触りなどの要素を犠牲にしても大きな音が出るような改良がなされ（ヴァイオリン、フルートなど）、それに向かなかった楽器（ヴィオール属、リュート、リコーダーなど）が淘汰された。
sen.e: As a result, some of the musical instruments (violins and flutes, for example) have been improved to provide higher sound volume levels at the cost of other features such as delicate tones, easy-to-play features, pleasant tough, etc., and the other instruments (viols, lutes, recorders, etc.) which were not suitable for this adaptation have disappeared.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Consequently, some musical instruments (violins and flutes, for example) have been improved to provide higher sound levels at the cost of other features such as delicacy of tone, ease of playing, a pleasant touch, etc., and the other instruments (viols, lutes, recorders, etc.) that weren't suitable for this adaptation have disappeared.

Consequently, some musical instruments (violins and flutes, for example) have been improved to provide higher sound levels at the cost of other features such as delicacy of tone, ease of playing, a pleasant touch, etc., and the other instruments (viols, lutes, recorders, etc.) that weren't suitable for this adaptation have disappeared.

sen.j: それに対し、日本の楽器の多くはその淘汰を受けなかったからである。
sen.e: In contrast, most of the Wagakkis were not subjected to such adaptation.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Contrastingly, most Wagakki weren't subjected to such adaptations.
Contrastingly, most Wagakki weren't subjected to such adaptations.

sen.j: 和楽器ではむしろ室内で耳をこらしてデリケートな音色の変化を賞玩するために、音量よりも音色の洗練、追求に力が注がれた。
sen.e: In the case of Wagakkis, sophistication of tones rather than higher sound volume levels has been chased so that delicate changes in tones can be enjoyed in a quiet room.
In the case of Wagakki, the sophistication of tones rather than higher sound levels has been pursued so that delicate changes in tones could be enjoyed in a quiet room.
In the case of Wagakki, the sophistication of tones rather than higher sound levels has been pursued so that delicate changes in tones could be enjoyed in a quiet room.

sen.j: ただし音量の増大を目的とした改良も行なわれている（山田検校の箏改良など）。
sen.e: However, it is to be noted that some attempts to increase sound volume levels were also made (the improvement of Sos made by blind koto master YAMADA, for example).
However, it is to be noted that some attempts to increase sound levels were also made (such as in the improvement of the So made by the blind koto master YAMADA).
However, it is to be noted that some attempts to increase sound levels were also made (such as in the improvement of the So made by the blind koto master YAMADA).

sen.j: 一方、祭礼（祭囃子、神楽など）のために屋外で演奏される分野の楽器は、音量が大きい。
sen.e: On the other hand, Wagakkis used in the field of music played outdoors for festivals (festival music, Shinto music, etc.) can provide sufficiently high sound volume levels.
On the other hand, the Wagakki used in the field of music played outdoors at festivals (festival music, Shinto music, etc.) can provide sufficiently high sound levels.
On the other hand, the Wagakki used in the field of music played outdoors at festivals (festival music, Shinto music, etc.) can provide sufficiently high sound levels.

sen.j: 和太鼓、鉦、鐘、篳篥、横笛、ホラガイがこれに相当する。
sen.e: Such instruments include Wadaikos (Japanese drums), Kanes (cymbals and bells), Hichirikis (Japanese traditional recorders), Yokobues (Japanese flutes), and Horagais (trumpet shells).
Such instruments include the Wadaiko (Japanese drums), Kane (cymbals and bells), Hichiriki (Japanese traditional recorders), Yokobue (Japanese flutes) and Horagai (trumpet shells).
Such instruments include the Wadaiko (Japanese drums), Sho (gong), Kane (cymbals and bells), Hichiriki (Japanese traditional recorders), Yokobue (Japanese flutes) and Horagai (trumpet shells).

sen.j: また、浄瑠璃や長唄の三味線は歌舞伎・文楽・日本舞踊といった伝統芸能と共に用いられてきたため、広い劇場でもよく聞こえるよう、音量を増す方向に進化した。
sen.e: In addition, Shamisens used to accompany Joruri or Nagauta have also developed to increase their sound volume levels so that their sounds can be heard clearly even in a large concert hall because they have been also used for traditional performing arts such as Kabuki, Bunraku, and Nihon-buyo (traditional Japanese dance).

Additionally, the Shamisen used to accompany Joruri or Nagauta have also developed to increase their sound volume levels so that their sounds could be heard clearly even in large concert halls, because they have also been used for traditional performing arts such as Kabuki, Bunraku and Nihon-buyo (traditional Japanese dance).

Additionally, the Shamisen used to accompany Joruri or Nagauta have also developed to increase their sound volume levels so that their sounds could be heard clearly even in large concert halls, because they have also been used for traditional performing arts such as Kabuki, Bunraku and Nihon-buyo (traditional Japanese dance).

tit.j: 簡素な構造による微妙な音色の演奏表現
tit.e: Artistic expression by delicate tones with simple structure
Artistic expression with a simple structure of delicate tones
Artistic expression with a simple structure of delicate tones

sen.j: 木・竹・皮など天然素材を生かしたものが多く、近代・現代西洋音楽の複雑な機構を備えたピアノやベーム式フルートなどの楽器と比較すると、構造は簡潔である。
sen.e: Many of Wagakkis are made of natural materials such as wood, bamboo, leather, etc., and are simpler in structure than musical instruments such as pianos or Boehm flutes, which have a complicated structure required for early modern and modern Western music.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Many Wagakki are made of natural materials such as wood, bamboo, leather, etc., and are simpler in structure than musical instruments such as pianos or Boehm flutes, which have a complicated structure required for Western music of the early modern and modern eras.

Many Wagakki are made of natural materials such as wood, bamboo, leather, etc., and are simpler in structure than musical instruments such as pianos or Boehm flutes, which have a complicated structure required for Western music of the early modern and modern eras.

sen.j: 和楽器は、操作のための器具がシンプルであったり無かったりする。
sen.e: Wagakkis require only simple or no playing accessories.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Wagakki require only simple accessories or none at all.
Wagakki require only simple accessories or none at all.

sen.j: 西洋音楽は、その発達の段階で旋法から調性音楽に基づくようになり、純正律に代えて転調に有利な平均律を導入してきた。
sen.e: As Western music advanced from the musical-mode based stage to the tonal-music based stage, equal temperament, which is suitable for modulation, has been introduced instead of pure temperament.

As Western music advanced from the stage at which it was based on musical modes to the stage at which it was based more on tonality, the theory of equal temperament, which was suitable for modulation, was introduced and superceded pure temperament.

As Western music advanced from the stage at which it was based on musical modes to the stage at which it was based more on tonality, the theory of equal temperament, which was suitable for modulation, was introduced and superceded pure temperament.

sen.j: そのような体系化の中で、楽器に複雑な機構を要求するようにもなった。
sen.e: Such process also necessitated musical instruments to have complicated mechanisms.
This process also required musical instruments to have complicated mechanisms.
This process also required musical instruments to have complicated mechanisms.

sen.j: 日本の音楽ではこれらのことを実現するための複雑な機構を求めるケースは少なく、あっても調弦変えや持ち替えなど、演奏者の奏法上の工夫で十分対応できた。
sen.e: Traditional Japanese music seldom required such complicated mechanisms for these purposes, and even if there was such a need, players could satisfy it sufficiently by making full use of their playing techniques, such as change of tuning or change of holding style.

Traditional Japanese music seldom required such complicated mechanisms for these purposes, and even if there was such a need the player could satisfy it sufficiently by making full use of his playing techniques, such as through a change of tuning or a change in which the instrument was held.

Traditional Japanese music seldom required such complicated mechanisms for these purposes, and even if there was such a need the player could satisfy it sufficiently by making full use of his playing techniques, such as through a change of tuning or a change in which the instrument was held.

sen.j: 近世邦楽では特に、演奏家の直接的な操作でしか表現できない微妙な音色、音程、余韻の変化などを積極的に利用、追求して来た。
sen.e: In particular, for early modern Japanese music, delicate changes in tones, musical intervals, and pauses, which are able to be expressed only through direct manipulation by players, were positively utilized and chased.

Particularly, for early modern Japanese music delicate changes in tones, musical intervals and pauses, which could be expressed only through direct manipulation by the players, were positively utilized and pursued.

Particularly, for early modern Japanese music delicate changes in tones, musical intervals and pauses, which could be expressed only through direct manipulation by the players, were positively utilized and pursued.

sen.j: このような微妙なものに重きを置く考えは非常に根強いもので、現代でもほとんどの和楽器が基本的に江戸時代の姿を変えていない。
sen.e: Such a way of thinking which places stress on delicate matters is still highly respected in modern Japan, and most of Wagakkis have still basically maintained their original appearance of the Edo period.

Such a way of thinking, which places emphasis on delicate matters, is still highly respected in modern Japan, and most Wagakki have still basically maintained their original appearance of the Edo period.

Such a way of thinking, which places emphasis on delicate matters, is still highly respected in modern Japan, and most Wagakki have still basically maintained their original appearance of the Edo period.

sen.j: 西洋楽器の影響を受けて「近代化」したものが少なくない中国楽器とは対照的である。
sen.e: In contrast, many of Chinese traditional musical instruments have been "modernized" because of the influence of Western musical instruments.
Contrastingly, many Chinese traditional musical instruments have been "modernized" due to the influence of Western musical instruments.
Contrastingly, many Chinese traditional musical instruments have been 'modernized' due to the influence of Western musical instruments.

sen.j: また、楽器の改良もシンプルな方向に進むことが多かった。
sen.e: Furthermore, improvements on musical instruments were frequently made in a simple fashion.
Furthermore, improvements in musical instruments were frequently made in a simple manner.
Furthermore, improvements in musical instruments were frequently made in a simple manner.

sen.j: 尺八、幕末の一弦琴や二弦琴はその最たる例である。
sen.e: Typical examples include Shakuhachis, and one- or two-stringed Kotos which were popular at the end of the Edo period.
Typical examples include the Shakuhachi, and the one- and two-stringed Koto, which were popular at the end of the Edo period.
Typical examples include the Shakuhachi, and the one- and two-stringed Koto, which were popular at the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 簡潔さの中にこそ美があり、そこにこそ魂、霊が宿り、神や仏に近づくという日本古来の美意識、思想が音に反映された現れといえる。
sen.e: It can be said that this is the result of traditional Japanese esthetic philosophy or idea that only simplicity can provide beauty, only simplicity can foster souls and spirits, and only through simplicity people can approach God or Buddha, having been reflected on sounds.

It can be said that this resulted from the traditional Japanese esthetic philosophy, in which the idea that only simplicity can provide beauty, only simplicity can foster the soul and spirit, and only through simplicity people can one approach God or Buddha, was reflected in the sound of music.

It can be said that this resulted from the traditional Japanese esthetic philosophy, in which the idea that only simplicity can provide beauty, only simplicity can foster the soul and spirit, and only through simplicity people can approach God or Buddha, was reflected in the sound of music.

sen.j: ただし、近親調への転調は近世邦楽では非常に多い。
sen.e: However, modulation to related keys is very popular in early modern Japanese music.
However, modulation to related keys was very popular in early modern Japanese music.
However, modulation to related keys was very popular in early modern Japanese music.

sen.j: 例：箏・三味線における「楽曲途中での調弦変更（『転調』） 地歌を参照」) や、尺八・篠笛の「指穴半開」、「持ち替え」
sen.e: Examples: "changes of tuning (modulation)" in the course of a piece of music in the case of Sos and Shamisens (see Jiuta), or "half-opened finger holes" and "changes of holding style" in the case of Shakuhachi and Shinobue

Examples include "changes of tuning (modulation)" in the course of a piece in the case of the So and Shamisen (see Jiuta), or "half-open finger holes" and "changes of holding style" in the case of the Shakuhachi and Shinobue.

Examples include 'changes of tuning (modulation)' in the course of a piece in the case of the So and Shamisen (see Jiuta), or 'half-open finger holes' and 'changes of holding style' in the case of the Shakuhachi and Shinobue.

sen.j: 弥生時代から存在する和琴 (わごん)などを除き、ほとんどの楽器は中国大陸伝来 (胡弓は不明) のものに変化が加えられたものである。
sen.e: Most of Wagakkis were produced by modifying originals introduced from the Asian continent except those such as Wagons which have been present since the Yayoi period (it is unknown whether Kokyus are originated from the Asian continent or not).

Most Wagakki were produced by modifying the original instruments introduced from the Asian continent, except for those such as the Wagon, which have been present since the Yayoi period (it is unknown whether the Kokyu originated from the Asian continent).

Most Wagakki were produced by modifying the original instruments introduced from the Asian continent, except for those such as the Wagon, which have been present since the Yayoi period (it is unknown whether the Kokyu originated from the Asian continent).

sen.j: 材料が日本国内で入手しやすいものに変えられていった点 (ただし三味線や琵琶では江戸時代でも輸入材 である唐木が使われたことが少なくない) と、より繊細な音色が出せるような改良、また前述の「倍音」の追加が主な変化である。
sen.e: Major modifications include adoption of materials which were easily available in Japan (however, imported materials, or Karaki (wood imported from China), were frequently used even during the Edo period for Shamisens and Biwas), modifications to generate more delicate tones, and the above-described addition of "harmonics".

Major modifications include the adoption of materials that were easily available in Japan (however, imported materials, or Karaki (wood imported from China), were frequently used even during the Edo period for the Shamisen and Biwa), modifications to generate more delicate tones, and the above-described addition of "harmonics.".

Major modifications include the adoption of materials that were easily available in Japan (however, imported materials, or Karaki (wood imported from China), were frequently used even during the Edo period for the Shamisen and Biwa), modifications to generate more delicate tones, and the above-described addition of 'harmonics.'

sen.j: 和楽器の場合、弦楽器は糸 (絹糸) を用い、管楽器は竹でできているので、楽器、ひいては音楽を「糸竹 (いとたけ・しちく)」と呼ぶこともある。
sen.e: Because strings (silk strings) are used in stringed Wagakkis and bamboo are used in wind Wagakkis, Wagakkis, and even music played by them, are sometime referred to as "Ito-take or shi-chiku", which means strings and bamboos.

Because strings (silk strings) are used in stringed Wagakki and bamboo are used in wind Wagakki, the Wagakki, and even music played by them, are sometimes referred to as "Ito-take or shi-chiku," which means "strings and bamboo."

Because strings (silk strings) are used in stringed Wagakki and bamboo are used in wind Wagakki, the Wagakki, and even music played by them, are sometimes referred to as 'Ito-take or shi-chiku,' which means 'strings and bamboo.'

sen.j: 古代中国では楽器を材料で8種に分類し、これを「八音」と呼んだ。
sen.e: In ancient China, musical instruments were classified into eight categories depending on their materials used, and were referred to as "Hachion", which means eight sounds.
In ancient China, musical instruments were classified into eight categories depending on the materials used, and were referred to as "Hachion," which means "eight sounds."
In ancient China, musical instruments were classified into eight categories depending on the materials used, and were referred to as 'Hachion,' which means 'eight sounds.'

sen.j: 日本でも古くはこれに従ったが、普通は「弾き物 (弦楽器)」「吹き物 (管楽器)」「打ち物 (打楽器)」に分けることが多い。
sen.e: For this reason, even in Japan, musical instruments were once referred to as "Hachion", but now they are commonly classified into three categories: "Hajikimonos (stringed musical instruments)", "Fukimonos (wind musical instruments)", and "Uchimonos (percussion musical instruments)".

For this reason, even in Japan musical instruments were once referred to as "Hachion," but now they're commonly classified into three categories: "Hajikimono (stringed instruments)," "Fukimono (wind instruments)" and "Uchimono (percussion instruments)."

For this reason, even in Japan musical instruments were once referred to as 'Hachion,' but now they're commonly classified into three categories: 'Hajikimono' (stringed instruments), 'Fukimono' (wind instruments) and 'Uchimono' (percussion instruments).

sen.j: 和楽器においても西洋楽器と同様に弦楽器、木管楽器、金管楽器、打楽器に分ける事はできる。
sen.e: As is the case with Western musical instruments, Wagakkis can also be classified into four categories: stringed musical instruments, wood-wind musical instruments, brass musical instruments, and percussion musical instruments.
As is the case with Western musical instruments, Wagakki can also be classified into four categories: stringed instruments, woodwind instruments, brass instruments and percussion instruments.
As is the case with Western musical instruments, Wagakki can also be classified into four categories: stringed instruments, woodwind instruments, brass instruments and percussion instruments.
